Hi Oliver,
   I found "A Simplified Formula For Proportions" described=
 here: 
   http://edis.ifas.ufl.edu/pd006
worked well for automatically det=
ermining the novelty search sample probability.  I wrote a NoveltyKNN class=
 that calculates the sample size using this formula: If the number of evalu=
ations+population size is known then the probability is only calculated onc=
e at class construction, but as more common the case the number of evaluati=
ons against the archive is open ended/unknown, so I cooked up a method to r=
ecalculate the sample size (archive_chance) periodically.  The source code =
to NoveltyKNN is over on the SharpNeat forum see the zip file "SharpNeatV2_=
Keith.zip", here:
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/sharpneat/DBo4CNq=
NLjg

I initially tried to use the threshold method you were discussing pre=
viously but found it to be much less efficient/poor approximation for novel=
ty. I tested by simply simulating test "behaviors" randomly drawn from a 2d=
 normal distribution, and later queried and graphed what the archive though=
t was novel. Probabilistic sampling approximated quite well what you would =
expect to be novel in this simple test case (high novelty scores on the tai=
ls, low scores around the mean) whereas the threshold method appeared to pr=
oduce jagged/inconsistent results by comparison, was not at all a smooth ap=
proximation to the actual novelty landscape. Perhaps my implementation of t=
he threshold method was flawed, but considering the simplicity good results=
 using the probabilistic sampling, I decided to run with it.

Regards,
Keit=
